required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Ramosetron OD Tablet and Postdischarge Nausea and Vomiting
clinical_study.official_title: Effects of Ramosetron Orally Disintegrating Tablet on the Prophylaxis of Postdischarge Nausea and Vomiting in High-risk Patients Undergoing Day Surgery Under General Anesthesia

brief_summary.textblock: Postoperative nausea and vomiting after general anesthesia is one of the common anesthetic complications. If the patient is discharged from the hospital after surgery, proper treatment may be delayed or impossible if nausea and vomiting occurred. Thus, it is necessary to prevent these symptoms beforehand. Patients who underwent day-surgery will be treated with prophylactic ramosetron orally disintegrating tablets to determine whether the frequency of nausea and vomiting is decreased when the patient returned home after discharge.

primary_outcome.measure: The change in the occurrence of postoperative nausea
primary_outcome.time_frame: Postoperative 30 minute, 3 hour, 24 hour, and 48 hour

primary_outcome.measure: The change in the occurrence of postoperative vomiting
primary_outcome.time_frame: Postoperative 30 minute, 3 hour, 24 hour, and 48 hour

secondary_outcome.measure: The change in the severity of postoperative nausea
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Postoperative 30 minute, 3 hour, 24 hour, and 48 hour
secondary_outcome.description: Numerical rating scale range from 0 to 100 (0 = no pain, 100 = the most severe pain imaginable)

secondary_outcome.measure: The change of patient's satisfaction score
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Postoperative 30 minute, 3 hour, 24 hour, and 48 hour
secondary_outcome.description: Numerical rating scale range from 0 to 100 (0 = no pain, 100 = the most severe pain imaginable)

secondary_outcome.measure: The change in the number of postoperative administration of rescue antiemetic drug
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Postoperative 30 minute, 3 hour, 24 hour, and 48 hour

intervention.description: Ramosetron orally disintegrating tablet 0.1 mg is administered after discharge (postoperative day 1 and day 2)

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Patients who undergo day-surgery under general anesthesia and are discharged on the day of surgery
Exclusion Criteria:
- Pregnancy or breastfeeding
- Patients who are taking other serotonin receptor antagonists
- Patients who have galactose intolerance or Lapp lactase deficiency
- patients who have glucose-galactose malabsorption
